reviewText:
Overall rating is 6/10.

This is a somewhat fun, addictive and non-traditional soccer (or football, if you will) game. Instead of controlling any of the characters themselves, you instead get access to a wide range of powerups that you can use to influence the outcome of the game. Initially, you begin with just mines that you can place to blow up the enemy players (or even your own, if you're so inclined) but as you progress in the game, you get access to other powerups (some of which include cows that run people over, rockets, UFOs that pick players up, rabid fans that help your team kick the ball, etc).

Each match in the single player mode has an objective, which may range from win the match within the time limit" to "get the score to exactly 5:4". Therefore
date: there are times where you'll have to use your weapons on your own team mates to manipulate the score.\n\nThe gameplay is relatively fun
voteText: although the game suffers immensely from imbalance. Some items
helpfulPercent: such as the Red card (that sends a player off the field) are incredibly overpowered and ruin all the challenge in the game. I would actually recommend trying to avoid some overpowered items if possible
votesHelpful: as they completely eliminate any difficulty in the game
votesTotal: which further removes any real incentive to use different tactics to complete the objectives.\n\nThe graphics and sound are pretty mediocre
votesFunny: although none of this is particularly bothersome for a game of this nature.\nApparently this game has multiplayer too
commentsCount: although I haven't tried it out yet. I imagine it'd be relatively fun
column16: particularly if you were able to restrict the use of some items (i.e. the aforementioned red card).\n\nOverall
column17: I would recommend you try out the game
column18: as it did hold my attention enough to actually beat it."

reviewText:
Truly this game is the zenith of football simulation. Watching the players performing a ballet of football skills like geishas at court, whilst conjuring the most splendid of tactical plays is a symphony to the purist's heart. When one places a cheeky landmine in front of the opponent's goal keeper it brings to mind the great tactics of Clough, Shankly and Ferguson.

The football revolution is here and it's packing airstrikes.

reviewText:
Make no mistake. FootLOL is a hilariously fun game. Just don't expect some football. This game deals in chaos. If your toons aren't getting blown up, knocked down, displaced, abducted, ravaged, and etc then you are probably doing it wrong.

The game offers several levels divided between a few planets and it's guaranteed to give you at least 3 hours worth of content. Getting the game at 100% only requires you to play up to level 35 so keep that in mind if you plan on going for it.

My only complaint about this game is that I have to reinvite people whenever our match ends. A lobby would be great.

reviewText:
FootLoL enticed me with its soccer theme and its madness on the field. Upon playing the game a little bit more, it's definitely not for me. I'm not a casual gamer by any means but do like playing games like this in-between other games. Reason I cannot recommend it is that it gets boring after a while. I may find it boring, you may not. Heck, I'm sure kids would like this game.

An emphasis on strategy should be put here rather than soccer. Although soccer seems to be the main theme of the game, you (as the player) have about zero control over the players on the pitch. The only thing you can control is placing tactical objects or weapons on the pitch. Some of the weapons that are included are land mines (which blow-up opponents when they are near), meteorites where meteors will literally come from the sky and hit the field, a herd of cows can be used to flatten your opponent, ball multipliers to increase the amount of goals you score when the ball goes into the net and not limited to turrets. Counter-measures are also included to help you defend your players from your opponent. Armor can be equipped, bubble spheres can be erected to protect players (or the ball from moving forward), speed boosts or speed traps, protective bubble shields that can block ball and players as well as the ability to expand the opponents net. There are A LOT of weapon options in game which is a great feature.

The players themselves do not make much of an effort to dodge any of the obstacles. Essentially, they have positions but players will move near the ball if it's close by. The game feels pretty balanced. Deciding which weapons to take to the battle"field can literally make a night and day difference in the score. Choose the wrong power-ups or use them too much and watch your score stay stagnant. There are a few game modes in FootLoL : championship mode where you tour the world/solar system
date: quick match and multiplayer mode. Most players will most likely choose to pursue championship mode before anything else. In championship mode you start with a certain amount of slots and certain amount of abilities. As the game progresses (and the better you do in-games)
recommended: the cash-rewards become a lot bigger. The AI within the game also becomes progressively difficult although most of the time beating him isn't the most difficult. Meeting certain objectives laid out before hand is where the challenge lies. Each match is timed and the team with the most goals when the clock hits zero
hoursPlayed: wins. The better the performance and the more conditions that are met means a better payout. Don't forget though
voteText: your opponent can possess the same abilities as you!\n\nVisually
helpfulPercent: the game play is cool because there is a lot going. Watching meteors fall from the sky while sheep are running across the field while blobs are blocking certain players can get insane. As I said
votesHelpful: visually watching it is cool. Playing it is a completely different story (because this is where the limitations start coming in).\n\nThe biggest issue for me is that this feels like a game I would play on the iPad. I understand the "mobile gaming" platform is slowly evolving and yes programmers should get some credit where credit is due
votesTotal: but I certainly do not like purchasing games that could be played on an iPad (on a rig that costs a lot more than one). As I've said
votesFunny: if you're into strategy and something a little bit different with some outlandish effects
commentsCount: I'm sure you'll enjoy the game. If you're here for some soccer or some sort of inclusiveness
column16: it's not here. If they added a gimmick or something in which you could control players
column17: I'm sure that would have added another depth to the game.\n\nOverall
column18: I won't recommend it as it's not my cup of tea. However
column19: if you do like this (even for a full price)
column20:
I would recommend getting it. I think there was enough put into the game to get enough bang for your buck.


RATING : 6.0/10

reviewText: I'm not a fan of football games, but this did make me rethink the fun we can have with football. This game's genre (what I think) is Real Time Strategy (although you cannot control the players), because this game needs you to make decisions whenever you think the team might need some support, and because this game is not turn-based (as you can see in the video in steam store). If you play Battlefield 4, it's like having a pocket sized commander mode, very small map, giving support to your fellowmen. I did enjoy doing that,, until I've done around 40% of the Earth Stage. Since I'm a perfectionist, I tend to get all the challenges done (challenges are written at the top left of the screen, with scores you have to have in order to complete the challenge). This REALLY gets harder and harder for me, as a strategy game newbie. I did also see myself doing some facepalm because I was being serious with just a game *facepalm*. For now, I would recommend you buy this, instead of buying snacks that will be a pleasure for few minutes, and buy this game, which will be playable for such a long time. It's definately not a game you would want for Dota2-like competition, but rather for fun like throwing grenades at each other in PAYDAY2. So, yeah, don't buy if you're pro at Dota2...\nOther informations- From what I've played, 1 stage is around 1;00~2;00, with endless replayability. It does not have any RPG features, except maybe the skills or upgrades you can buy with the income.\nAnd last but not the least, the game is VERY light compared to the price, with 96MB of installation and around the half for download... Guys, I really don't know if I should recommend this.. -.-

reviewText:
What is FootLOL: Epic Fail League?

Genre: strategic football/soccer game with RPG elements
Setting: funny stickman characters (=the players) battling for victory in football/soccer matches
Difficulty: 3/10 --> basically easy
Length: 5 hours for a single playthrough, up to 10 for getting all rewards
Mode: singleplayer campaign, multiplayer (abandoned)


The positive aspects:

- fresh and funny gameplay. You do not control the players themselves, but have to guide them to scoring goals by using power-ups in the right way
- lots of power-ups with different characteristics: meteors, cows, flak cannons, air strikes, shields, teleporters, ball clones, crazy fans and a lot more
- RPG-ish upgrades to improve your team and cosmetics (new flags, eyes, hats etc.)
- Pretty nice sound effects, especially when you spam the pitch with different power-ups simultaneously


The negative aspects:

- strange goals. Sometimes it happens that you put the ball wide, but then it drops into the net, counting as a goal.
- gameplay gets repititive after a short time
- 2D/3D graphics mashup. You're getting used to that, but putting the 2D players into 3D would have been nice
- The biggest counterpoint surely is the strange tasks you have to complete. In most of the games you have to complete three tasks, which are always special scores. For example, for the first task the game wants you to lead by 3-0, for the second task to be down by 3-7, and for the third/final task to win by a 5-goal margin.
On the one hand, this gameplay element adds some tactical depth into the game as you sometimes have to support the opponent's team and sabotage your own squad. Otherwise - pardon me - strange thing to support somebody you have to beat, isn't it? Like corrupting the game. And I don't think that FIFA developed this game
- multiplayer is as good as dead, unfortunately


Result (and summary for those who have no time reading):

Ok, basically FootLOL is a fun football game with entertaining gameplay and a huge variety of power-ups to reach your goals. Though there are some counterpoints, like strange goals and tasks to complete, you can have a nice time spamming the field with cows and meteors. I recommend you to try it out (at sales time)!

reviewText:
An amazing take on Football, instead of actually controlling the players or perhaps managing a team you are tasked with essentailly sabotaging the other team using as many skills as possible, these range from blowing them up with mines to spawning footballs on your team so they can take shots while the keeper is on the floor dying. I haven't been able to try the Multiplayer aspect but I assume it's pretty much the same but with more havoc. There is a skill progression in it however so it would be wise not to venture to that mode until you have aquired all skills as you have no idea what your opponent may have.

8.5/10 For being fun, hilarious and amazing to play with extremely responsive controls.

YouTube Gameplay: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=E7niF6GMzn8

reviewText: This game is fun when you first play it, but as you get farther and unlock new items, it becomes redundant. The players move via AI but seem to suck horribly or do insanely well. You can't control anyone, all you can do is use items on your team, or sabotage the other team. Sounds fun, but only for a little bit. You have a nice variety of items, but most play out the same: give resistance to your team, or make eneimes fly everywhere. Maybe if you had the option to be your own team, then this game would have variety since I'm making my own action and would be fun. But instead you have to rely on your stupid AI team to fight against a stupid AI team and pray they do the right thing. Items are all the same pretty much, and voice get incredibly annoying.\n\nNOTE: If you want to play this game and actually have any fun, play multiplayer, or screw your entire AI team and rely on yourself by using the items to explode the ball to the goal. It makes the game fun, mainly because everyone on the field is flying everywhere and screaming.

reviewText:
FootLOL is a fun take on football, but unfortunately manages to stay fresh for only a few hours or so. It's best played in short sessions of about 30 minutes. You don't actually control any of the players but you can help them out by keeping them safe, or by hurting your enemies. You do this by using power-ups.

Your team will shoot when they're near the goal and they'll do the best they to keep the enemy from scoring. Finishing ('winning' is the better word here) matches will earn you money and completing objectives will earn you even more money. This money is used to use more power-ups, or to let you choose more of them, or to improve the AI of your team, for example.

The graphics are simple and the sound effects are very basic but it has a certain charm, I guess.
There are several worlds to complete so it will take at least a couple of hours to complete it. I grew tired of it before that, but it was a fun, unusual game anyway.

If you like casual games about football/soccer FootLOL is the game you're looking for.

[Rating: 72/100]

reviewText:
Got it for sale for 1.50 $, it's well worth the price, not sure if 5 is a good deal.

The gameplay in itself is amusing, you have a football team of stick figures doing their own thing, and you can help them by cheating your way to victory: speed up that guy about to make a goal, maybe put flames on the ball itself so the goalie is scared of touching it? Skills range from simple things such as the infamous red card to strategic bombardment and UFO's.
Obviously some combinations are more unbalanced than others, ban all enemies from the field, summon some fans and drop a few extra balls to get as many goals as you want.

...which actually isn't helpful, since the game gives you a few objectives for extra in-game cash, and they're all reach a score of X:Y"

reviewText: So many times I laughed at the sheer ridiculousness of this game.  Not sure I have ever played a game where I have to cripple my own team's chances in order to reach an objective, but it's so much fun to throw meteors around and watch all of the damage.  It's so much fun to play!\n\nThat said, it can get monotonous after a while.  It's really easy to use the same tactics and power-ups from match to match and go on a crazy win streak (at least through the beginning of the game).  I still highly recommend this gem.

reviewText:
It's ... surprisingly enjoyable and entertaining and easily among the top two football game on Steam.

FootLOL is a simple game, clearly designed for the casual and mobile crowd.

But unlike many cheap mobile to PC ports it is just as fun on the PC and very much polished and fun. It's also very fairly priced.

This won't be the best game you ever played, you won't play it for hours on end. But the time spend with it will almost certainly be enjoyable.

reviewText:
Hello, My name is DuffMan!!!!.....!!
im going to critique this as non bias as possible!

So i see this on steam on sale at the time very cheap $3.70c or somthing (geusstimate*) think why not , it looks silly it's cheap i'll get my money's worth if i play 10mins of it.
2 hours later...Footlol is complete chaos!
You start in championship mode" (campaign) and start to learn basic technique's such as laying mines. At first this all seem's pretty straight forward so there is a slight grind at the start
date: but i didn't find myself bored of blowing up these funny little footbal player's!\nAs you continue to earn cash to buy upgrade's or avatar's if you wish
recommended: although i would like to see more for online expression
hoursPlayed:
every gamer takes pride in there charachter's but that last bit was entirly personal opinion :P

But the upgrade's seem quite a sufficient balance of defence and counter's and sometime's just have unbelievable resulst's!

All in all

reviewText:
“FootLOL: Epic Fail League” is the kind of game you can jump into for a few minutes, have some laughs, and turn off to do something else.  It’s currently retailing on Steam for five bucks, which isn’t a bad deal all things considered.  Had the game been ten or possibly even fifteen bucks, I’d have my doubts about recommending the game altogether…there’s just not enough going on to justify a high price tag (I’m looking at you, “Goat Simulator”).  As it stands, “FootLOL: Epic Fail League” is a fun and chaotic game worth checking out, especially if you have a warped sense of humor like myself.

reviewText:
Real soccer could learn some valuable lessons about being interesting from this game.

Just watch the videos; it's really that crazy.

The whole premise revolves around cheating so that a balanced game, between mediocre AIs, tips in the favor of your team.  This works really well as a game mechanic, because the cheating process is versatile and open to mistakes.   You can speed boost your defender by the ball, the player he passes to and then explode the goalie, or you can accidentaly speed boost the opponents offense and blow up your defender.  Everything happens super fast, which gives it a really zany vibe.

The game offers incentives to play in favor of the opponents early in the match, which is a fresh approach to the issue of difficulty.  Sure you can win with a little skill, but setting yourself up for a big comeback and then pulling it off takes finese.  It really says something when a game encourages you to antagonize yourself in a positive way.

reviewText:
This game is surprising fun. Scoring goals is about the only thing that is the same as really football. I love being able to drop heaps of balls just after landmining the goal keeper - quick way to score goals. I have to say, watching both sets of players fly everywhere is actually more fun than winning.

I haven't yet played multiplayer but I suppose it would be quite fun as playing the AI is a little easy at times.

I highly recommend this game if you after a cheap, fun, time-waster and love worms and blowing things up. Being a football fan is just a bonus.

reviewText:
This. This was fun.
The 'campaign' in FootLOL is a series of very short (< 3mins) matches where you basically try to win the match by blowing up the other players (with mines, fireballs, and charging cows) and also by giving your players some temporary advantages (such as speed boost, shields, and sparta combat gear).  Then there's the whole suite of abilities that alter the field of play, like sticky goo, holodomes that block balls, flaming soccer balls that goalies won't defend against, fans that charge the field in uniform to both play and take out the opponents, and many others.

It is absolutely awesome to send dozens fans to storm the field and then let loose a bunch of extra soccer balls in front of the opponents goal.  Scoring comes fast and furious even without blowing up the goalie.

While this great little game doesn't take too long to complete (2 hours to complete the many matches for Earth, and then another 2 hours total for the Moon, Mars, and Saturn) it sure is a lot of fun.   8 out of 10.

reviewText: Fun fun game

reviewText:
What this game is about?
It's about using powerups to manipulate playing field in order to score goals or fulfill some aims of the stage like for example winning in a set score 3:2.

This game is a little indie game, where you go through more or less chaotic stages where you and your opponent use different power ups in order to achieve victory by any means. Player with most goals win the match.

Some exapmles of basic power ups:
- haste to one footballer for about 10 seconds
- stop time for about 5 seconds
- create some shield that blocks the ball
- meteor that can knock players down for a moment and destroy shields
- mine than knocks down players for about three seconds and can push the ball in a direction opposite to the side of explosion (physics, you know?)

The player also have possibility to buy some advancements like more income or slight advance in speed of footballers (that look like 2d cartoony like characters, funny enough).

There is one basic exploit. About an hour into the game and I have found one stage that you can reload to have goals like win with goal pattern 1:0, 3:0 and so on. Such a game takes about 10-30 seconds to win and gives 750$. Upgrading income by 4% costs 500%. Please do the math yourself and calculate how much time would it take to upgrade your income to a maximum level (25 times 4%) thus giving you a permanent upgrade of 100% more income.

Rince and repeat such a stage that you can complete under 10 seconds and earn so much money in about 2 hours of gameplay that you will (yes, will) win the game without any difficulty at all.

Thus such an exploit is quite a fun killer to me. The game is still nice to play and use really wacky powerups (cow stampede, meteors, bombarding, spawning additional balls so you can have scores like 38:19, so on and so forth) but why shouldn't a player not use such an exploit to win the game easily? There is no motivation to play more levels, and some of them can drag itself for about 2 minutes. This can be long, believe me.

----------
For anyone interested in joining in on completing your own backlog; check it out here - http://steamcommunity.com/groups/completingthebacklog/discussions/5/530645446320364338/

reviewText:
Fun little game. Pretty casual but in a good Plants vs. Zombies" way. 7/10

Pros:
1. Lots of unique powers
date:
keeping each match feeling different and fresh
2. Replayability is pretty high
3. Can be played in short bursts or for long periods of time

Cons:
1. Art style works but could use some more detail. Feels bland
2. The randomness of the "soccer players" was a little frustrating
3. Casual (I'm never the biggest fan of "casual")

Casual gameplay has a tendency to deter me. However
recommended: there is enough variation here to recommend this game to anyone who enjoys games. This one wont keep my attention very long but I could find myself coming back to it every so often."
